block.p: Anne Frances Collins, a daughter of Dr. Mary H. Collins and Dr. John J. Collins Jr. of Wellesley Hills, Mass., was married yesterday to Frank Henry Goodyear III, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Goodyear Jr. of Phoenix. The Rev. Thomas J. Hogan, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul in Wellesley, Mass. Robert S. Hurlbut Jr., an Episcopal lay reader, took part in the ceremony.

Mrs. Goodyear, 30, graduated magna cum laude from Brown University. She is a candidate for a Ph.D. in art history from the University of Texas, writing her dissertation on artistic collaborations between scientists and artists in the 1960's. Last month she completed an appointment as a visiting assistant professor of art history at the University of Virginia.

Anne Frances Collins, a daughter of Dr. Mary H. Collins and Dr. John J. Collins Jr. of Wellesley Hills, Mass., was married yesterday to Frank Henry Goodyear III, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Goodyear Jr. of Phoenix. The Rev. Thomas J. Hogan, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul in Wellesley, Mass. Robert S. Hurlbut Jr., an Episcopal lay reader, took part in the ceremony.

Mrs. Goodyear, 30, graduated magna cum laude from Brown University. She is a candidate for a Ph.D. in art history from the University of Texas, writing her dissertation on artistic collaborations between scientists and artists in the 1960's. Last month she completed an appointment as a visiting assistant professor of art history at the University of Virginia.

Her father is an emeritus professor of surgery at Harvard University Medical School and a former chief of thoracic and cardiac surgery at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. Her mother is a psychiatrist at McLean Hospital in Belmont, Mass., and at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston.

Mr. Goodyear, 33, is a visiting assistant professor of American studies at George Washington University in Washington. He graduated from Princeton and received master's and Ph.D. degrees in American studies from the University of Texas at Austin. In September he will begin as a Smithsonian postdoctoral fellow at the National Museum of American Art, where he will rewrite his dissertation, on tourism in 19th-century America, for publication as a book. His father is the director of the Heard Museum in Phoenix.
